content: The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" recognizes the threat of international terrorism to the United States and the need for legal action against those who support it. The purpose of this Act is to provide access to the court system for victims of terrorist attacks in the US to pursue civil claims against those who have supported terrorism. It aims to give broad relief against individuals, entities, and foreign countries that have provided material support to terrorist organizations. The Attorney General can intervene to seek a stay of civil actions against foreign states, certified by the Secretary of State as being engaged in good faith. A court of the United States may stay proceedings against a foreign state if the Secretary of State certifies ongoing good faith discussions. The stay can last up to 180 days, with possible extensions upon recertification by the Secretary of State. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or amendment is held invalid, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act applies to civil actions pending or commenced after the date of enactment, related to injuries on or after September 11, 2001.
